reviewText:
After airing its 10 episode run in the fall of 2011 "Hung" was unable to hold on to its audience mainly because HBO insisted on broadcasting the series when new first-run network shows aired instead of airing it in the summer. So, sadly season 3 is the final year of one of the greatest cable shows ever produced and its the end of the road for Ray, played superbly by hunk Thomas Jane. In December, 2011 HBO officially announced it had axed "Hung".

 The third year continued to grow in both story content and acting as Thomas Jane proved he could be sexy, soft, rough, intelligent and manly...all attributes of the perfect guy. Ray is simply a hot property and he continues making a living being an escort for women only (unfortunately). Things really take off as Lenore, once a friend of Rays, seeks revenge against him and his pimp for stealing a business idea she had by transforming a young, hunky waiter into the next big stud on the block who works with the asset God gave him.

 I won't say if we do finally get to see Ray's huge "tool" this season, but it is unfortunate there are not going to be more seasons. Television doesn't get this good.

 There are a slew of bonuses on this two-disc set including deleted scenes,
the featurette "Hung: Inside the Series", "Pimpin' Ain't Easy", the Wellness centre Walkthrough, Damon and Darby's music video, "Where Is Henry Ford?", an Alternate Ending and 4 audio commentaries.

This show was far better than it's name. Too bad they didn't call it something else. Anyway, I picked up on the song, "Where is Henry Ford?" sung by the twins played by Sianoa Smit-McPhee and Charlie Saxton. I think it was episode 6 of season 3 but I'm not sure. I've been trying to find out more about it like who wrote it, the lyrics, was it written for the show, etc. It caught my interest because I never hear any songs by the younger generation (millennials) that express their feelings about the state of the world and their place in it. This may have been the first and it made me think back to people like Neal Young who expressed the feelings of my own generation. It didn't matter to me that it sounded like a song you might sing with your friends at casual gathering - someone picks up a guitar and starts singing. What was interesting was that it was folksy and it was relevant.

I was really excited for this show, and it has some good elements to it: the strong, well-developed characters are the female characters, and they mostly move the action along throughout the seasons; Ray's hypermasculinity is portrayed as a bad thing instead of being celebrated (although this is simultaneously a negative element of the show, since we don't get the see Ray actually please his clients, going so far as to pressure them into continuing activities they rejected on multiple occasions); and the messages portrayed by Tanya's Wellness Center are empowering, sometimes. Lenore is 100% my favorite character, she's hilarious and powerful, I love her actress. Tanya's actress plays her character perfectly too.

But I think there are too many bad elements weighing down the show to say that I really enjoyed it. When I first read the synopsis of this show, I expected it to be very progressive. I expected the protagonist to be dynamic, and to receive portrayals of his sex scenes with his clients that were  genuinely sexy, sensual, and pleasing to the intended audience. But Ray is just an old, misogynist (and spoiler alert: transmisogynist) grump of a man who occasionally 'learns lessons' through his fuck-ups with women but never experiences any long term changes. He's manipulative, selfish, and entirely unappealing to listen to; I feel bad for all of his clients, having to deal with someone so unjustifiably into himself. All of the men in the show are unreliable, which I assume is an intended theme, but Ray's whole deal got real old real quick. Outside of a disappointing protagonist, the show falls short in its monotonous storyline. Ray gets a client, he and/or Tanya does something extremely inconsiderate, Lenore does something mean and unexpected, Ray gets jealous of Jason, every now and then Tanya creates problems for herself by talking to Charlie and kind of taking his advice...

and then the show ended without any real resolutions.

Excellent elements to this series, enough to keep me watching, but ultimately it comes up flat and not just because the season ended abruptly. I love the idea of a "regular guy" who falls into this industry because he feels he has no other choice. I love the idea of an insecure lady trying to find her power as a pimp. Love the mentor pimp and rival pimp ideas. Even love the idea that the perfect couple in highschool have these less than average children. The problem is that the idea never gives you satisfaction.
  The primary lady pimp should have been played for high comedy. You should have been willing to sympathize with her instead of finding her journey uncomfortable and annoying. There should have been some pay off in watching her. It was good for her character to stumble, but with each stumble she should have found her "pimp power". For example, I think she should have figured out a way to tell Mike that he was an accidental ho, at first he was disgusted , but later came on board. The fact that she ran away and was too scared to talk to Mike, TWICE, was stupid. Her standing up to her mother should have given us a pay off, but it never did. She could have learned to be like the pimp version of the lady in "Fried Green Tomatoes" , but never did.
  They should not have gone so long with the story lines with the kids. There should have been more storylines, but with shorter payoffs. Instead of the ex-wife finding out, one of the kids should have found out and helped their dad. Or maybe they never find out and there are more lessons that he and the ex learn through having children that were different than they were in highschool.
  There is so much more that they could have done. Personally I kept watching because I was hoping that there would be a payoff but there never was.

The mark of a successful sitcom (in my opinion) is this: you've established the characters. We know each of them well. Then they become more hilarious when they pretend to be something they are clearly not. In the case of Hung, in order for their hustle to work, Ray and Tanya must do something they weren't great at previously: be professional. The pimp and the ho try to get a bank loan in the first episode to open what they call a "wellness center for women". The first class is free and it consists of Tanya pitching a lifestyle in which sex is part of your every day existence. Ray wanders into the frame towards the end of the class for the audience of women to see him after Tanya has already talked her students into feeling more aroused. But of course Lenore won't go away. Arguably the person with the best zingers in the writing, Rebecca Creskoff has the perfect comedic timing on her delivery of Tanya's nickname: "T-Brain".

Fans that thought the male prostitute profession plot had limited range are wrong. Lenore finds a much younger man who perfectly compliments what Ray is not. Ray wants to embrace his job much more than previously and sees the new ho as a threat. Ann Arbor fans may appreciate the address of the artsy wellness center as 734 (area code). Ray gets more projects that involve role playing. Ray seems to almost border sex addiction. Tanya seems more desperate than Walter White (Breaking Bad). I think the writing is strong enough to give the characters much more humanity than say Californication. The nudity in Hung seems much less gratuitous.

The extras (you know I gotta have my extras) are OK. I highly recommend the Alternate Ending of Episode 10. The abrupt ending to the franchise is a little easier to take if you check it out. Charles the pimp says that there are only 3 certain things in life: "Death, taxes and horny sonza bitches."

The economy is bad and Ray Drecker (Thomas Jane) has lost his teaching job. What better way to make some money but to put his exceptional "asset" to work. With his friend Tanya (Jane Adams) as his pimp, Ray gets to work. The premise seemed to be losing steam by Season 3. Drecker is in his early 40's and starting to look tired and weathered. How much longer can he stay in business. Enter the conniving Lenore (Rebecca Creskoff)and a new young "escort" and his odd-ball girlfriend and the conflict continues.
Ray and Tanya want to keep their business honest and simple. Tanya opens a Wellness Center for Women as a cover for Ray's services.
Now the story goes in all directions. We have competing males "escorts" and more conniving and back stabbing on all sides. Ray seems to really enjoy his work and is constanting getting emotionally involved with "clients". Jealousies arise and they can only lead to disaster.
Although the series is enjoyable, I was wondering what the point was. Aren't there moral implications with what Ray and Tanya are doing? Health considerations? I guess we need to overlook those questions and just follow the story. Amazingly as the season progesses, we see the show centers more around evolving personal relationships.  Ray's ex-wife (Anne Heche) is becoming more human and learning to live her own life without relying on the men in her life. Their twins have a lesser role this season. Tanya gets physically and financially involved with another pimp. Ray learns one client is not who she appears to be. In the end, this season is about the conflict between Lenore and Ray and Tanya. It can't end well as Lenore continues to scheme to be the Pimp Queen of Detroit.
It's hard to imagine so many women are willing to pay $600 on an ongoing basis for Ray's services. Detroit is ecomonically depressed but you can barely tell that by this show.
HBO canceled this series so we end Season 3 with cliff hangers and questions that will never be answered... just as my interest in the show was returning.
